docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The Clinton Administration proposal to add a voluntary prescription drug benefit to Medicare beginning in 2002 requires an initial monthly premium of $24 per beneficiary (editorial, Oct. 26). This premium appears to be unrealistically low.
docs.abstract: Robert W Kalman letter says $24 monthly premium for proposed Medicare drug benefit is unrealistically low (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    The Clinton Administration proposal to add a voluntary prescription drug benefit to Medicare beginning in 2002 requires an initial monthly premium of $24 per beneficiary (editorial, Oct. 26). This premium appears to be...

docs.lead_paragraph: Health insurance companies in New York are starting to pay as much for prescription drugs as they pay for care of hospitalized patients, a stunning change in direction for the region's health care dollars. The effects of these rising drug costs are felt at every point, from the manufacturers battling with Congress and the White House to the doctor pressured to prescribe a drug preferred by a health maintenance organization to the shopper at the pharmacy counter who learns that her asthma medication will cost twice as much as it did last month.

headline.main: Rising Costs of Medications Take Bigger Share of Insurance Outlays

docs.abstract: Health insurance companies in New York are starting to pay as much for prescription drugs as they pay for care of hospitalized patients, a stunning change in direction for region's health care dollars; effects of these rising drug costs are felt at every point, from manufacturers battling with Congress and White House to doctor pressured to prescribe a drug preferred by health maintenance orgn to shopper who learns that his asthma medication will cost twice as much as it did last month; for the insurance industry, shift in health care costs is prompting health maintenance orgns to change ways patients pay for drugs, and in some cases, passing on the increase directly to consumers, or trying to persuade hospitals to absorb some of new burden; some employers, faced with rising premiums, are requiring workers to pay 20 percent of each prescription, rather than continuing practice of a fixed co-payment (M)
